Bill de hï¿½ra wrote:

> Paul Holser wrote:
> 
>  > ah, but to make time to get such a thing going....8^)  probably best
>  > to contribute to TestNG instead.
> 
> It's not about that, it's about who has commit access. Junit 3.8,1
> was release in Sept 2002. As such it looks like a dead/abandoned
> project to me.

Well, to be fair, it could just be a good example of the Open/Closed 
Principle at work. The number of extensions out there is much higher 
than the number of would-be replacements.

> No doubt forking to get to Junit 4 has crossed some
> peoples minds.

Yes.... when the language changes this much, and when all the big J2EE 
vendors are all up on Tiger, it'll be worth having something waiting for 
their users that looks less like a relic and more like an idiomatic 
advancement of the tool.

> I'll have to take a look at TestNG.

It appears that I do, too. What a shame that I waited so long to get a 
book out on JUnit. Part of me hopes that TestNG takes a long time to 
take off, just so I have some time to enjoy the fruit of my labor.
